text: hi all - we at <https://www.risescience.com/|Rise Science> are exploring podcast advertising and newsletter advertising as possible customer acquisition channels. if anyone has had any success with either, i would love to chat (have lots of questions :slightly_smiling_face: ) - ty!

elements.text: hi all - we at
Rise Science
are exploring podcast advertising and newsletter advertising as possible customer acquisition channels. if anyone has had any success with either, i would love to chat (have lots of questions
) - ty!

text:
We've done a few newsletter sponsorships. A few things we've learned:

-A newsletter that offers several days at a time is better— it provides more opportunity for brand recognition and to peak someone's interest with messaging over several days
-Be careful with how ads are displayed in the newsletter. The most successful are the ones that match the style of the rest of the newsletter. If they stand out (i.e. a designed graphic for an ad but an all text newsletter) folks skip over them and our click through rates have been awful.
-when newsletters share their metrics, ask about click rates. They'll usually share list size, but find out what a successful ad looks like. We just ran one in a newsletter with 90,000 people and we got <100 clicks.
-look to smaller publications! We are in the political tech space and we ran simultaneous ads one week in POLITICO — a major industry publication— and 730DC, a local publication that is more focused on restaurants and things to do around the city. we actually had way better results in 730DC — their ad design was great and our audience was still reading it because they are interested in what is going on in their community.

elements.text:

-A newsletter that offers several days at a time is better— it provides more opportunity for brand recognition and to peak someone's interest with messaging over several days
-Be careful with how ads are displayed in the newsletter. The most successful are the ones that match the style of the rest of the newsletter. If they stand out (i.e. a designed graphic for an ad but an all text newsletter) folks skip over them and our click through rates have been awful.
-when newsletters share their metrics, ask about click rates. They'll usually share list size, but find out what a successful ad looks like. We just ran one in a newsletter with 90,000 people and we got <100 clicks.
-look to smaller publications! We are in the political tech space and we ran simultaneous ads one week in POLITICO — a major industry publication— and 730DC, a local publication that is more focused on restaurants and things to do around the city. we actually had way better results in 730DC — their ad design was great and our audience was still reading it because they are interested in what is going on in their community.

text:
thank you - this is so helpful.

my impression from my search so far is that there aren't any good aggregators of inventory yet (all aggregators I've found have been fairly small with access to a small number of newsletters with small audiences) - does this reflect what you've seen? it strikes me i'll likely have to go newsletter by newsletter and find opportunities by the newsletter and negotiate with each directly.

text: Hey folks! I’m working on writing a piece about excellent cover letters—specifically how to tell a story with your cover letter. Are there any cover letters that you’ve read that stick with you? What is it about those letters that make them particularly compelling? Can you think of any *one* element or quality in a cover letter that would make you stop reading and schedule an interview with the job applicant right away?

elements.text: Hey folks! I’m working on writing a piece about excellent cover letters—specifically how to tell a story with your cover letter. text:
At my day job we did a lot of different sponsorships in 2020. Some of those channels are carrying into 2021. Newsletter sponsorships were definitely not our highest converting types of sponsorships as far as lead volume was concerned. We got a lot more leads on things like website sponsorships.

I think it can work depending on the value of what you're offering and the graphics/copy, but newsletters are so all over the place. Like Theresa, we saw better results when we got shared over several days instead of one newsletter sponsorship. Also diving into some of those deeper metrics like open and click rate are so important. Thousands of subscribers mean nothing if the list is cold.

elements.text:
At my day job we did a lot of different sponsorships in 2020. Some of those channels are carrying into 2021. Newsletter sponsorships were definitely not our highest converting types of sponsorships as far as lead volume was concerned. We got a lot more leads on things like website sponsorships.

I think it can work depending on the value of what you're offering and the graphics/copy, but newsletters are so all over the place. Like Theresa, we saw better results when we got shared over several days instead of one newsletter sponsorship. Also diving into some of those deeper metrics like open and click rate are so important. Thousands of subscribers mean nothing if the list is cold.

text:
Even having a cover letter these days is extremely rare. I’m hiring a Content Marketing Manager right now and even for a role that is all about writing and storytelling, the vast majority of applicants did not include a real cover letter (even though the form requires one).

From the ones who actually submitted a cover letter, two things are key for me:
1. Bridging the gaps - no resume is going to be a 100% perfect fit for any job, so the cover letter is an opportunity to tell your story in a way that your resume cannot, bridging the gaps for the hiring manager.
2. Personality! I know personality in cover letters is a divisive topic, but anyone who is vulnerable enough to reveal something quirky or fun about themselves, even if it’s just their unique writing style, they have my attention.

elements.text:
Even having a cover letter these days is extremely rare. I’m hiring a Content Marketing Manager right now and even for a role that is all about writing and storytelling, the vast majority of applicants did not include a real cover letter (even though the form requires one).

From the ones who actually submitted a cover letter, two things are key for me:

Bridging the gaps - no resume is going to be a 100% perfect fit for any job, so the cover letter is an opportunity to tell your story in a way that your resume cannot, bridging the gaps for the hiring manager.

Personality! I know personality in cover letters is a divisive topic, but anyone who is vulnerable enough to reveal something quirky or fun about themselves, even if it’s just their unique writing style, they have my attention.

text: The one element that always makes me want to bring someone in for an interview — especially a content person — is when they communicate a sense of joy for what they do. That is not only a sign of an excellent writer, but it shows me that they’ll have an enthusiasm for the work, which won’t always go according to plan.

elements.text: The one element that always makes me want to bring someone in for an interview — especially a content person — is when they communicate a sense of joy for what they do. That is not only a sign of an excellent writer, but it shows me that they’ll have an enthusiasm for the work, which won’t always go according to plan.
